alo42 02-Sep-21 02:58 PM
Two questions on https://ethereum.stackexchange.com/questions/3542/how-are-ethereum-addresses-generated 1. Most wallets let you generate many Externally Owned Accounts (EOAs) all backed by one seed phrase. This SO answer states for public key -> EOA is "the last 40 characters / 20 bytes of this public key (Keccak-256)" How does this fact jive with being able to create multiple accounts from one public key? 2. Do all those separate EOAs use the same private key to sign transactions? And if so - doesn't this somewhat compromise pseudonymity - as someone can confirm that different EOAs are backed by the same private key? AKA, is there a cryptographic operation to determine if account 0xdsfsjdfjk34 and 0xdsf7s87r8r (invalid I know) were created from the same public keys? Thanks!
How are ethereum addresses generated?
What criteria does a valid Ethereum address need to fulfill? Is it just a random number in hexadecimal? Or does it need to be derived in a specific way, according to some cryptographic algorithms? ...
Blockchain forensics has been an interest of mine working at Wolfram with some crypto built-ins: https://blog.wolfram.com/2021/05/25/sleuthing-darkside-crypto-ransom-payments-with-the-wolfram-language/. So I'm always curious how law enforcement/private orgs can reverse engineer account ownership.
Dariia Porechna
Sleuthing DarkSide Crypto-Ransom Payments with the Wolfram Language...
Tracing Russian hackers' cryptocurrency funds using only public knowledge, some educated guesses and blockchain integration in the Wolfram Language.

thedarkjester 02-Sep-21 06:21 PM
There are two concepts within your statement, allow me to unpack a little: 1. You can use a private key to encrypt data (files or any data really) - the security is poor here however as anyone with the public key can decrypt it. 2. Signing data is encrypting data like you describe, but generally a hash of the data vs. all the data so that if anyone receiving the data can confirm it was you and your intent.

thedarkjester 03-Sep-21 08:33 AM
You hash the data, and then encrypt that hash. That allows the verifying party to use your public key to decrypt
This allows someone to then hash the data (file or message or whatever) and compare the decrypted hash from the signature against their hashed file's output
thedarkjester
This allows someone to then hash the data (file or message or whatever) and compare the decrypted hash from the signature against their hashed file's output

jarret
In the decentralizing intent video they are showing the message (data) gets hashed and then encrypted with your private key and then decrypted to get the hash of the message back. then somehow the message is also hashed on the receiver end which im getting confused about cause I think that means the message is sent as raw data too?
chibipunks 03-Sep-21 09:21 AM
yes that's signature: - calculate hash + sign it with your private key - raw data is sent along with the signature anyone can verify that the transaction is valid by checking with the address (which is derived from the public key) : verifying the signature checks that hashing the raw message is equal to the hash in the signature (so the message is not compromised) + the person who signed the hash has the private key from which the public key (ultimately the address) has been generated.

yeti 03-Sep-21 10:23 AM
Hi, I have a basic question - Is there a distinction between the nonce that identifies blocks being submitted to the blockchain compared to a transaction nonce? As I understand it, the former is a pseudorandom number that a miner varies until it happens to hash with the rest of the block data to give a valid pow solution, whereas a transaction nonce is a sequential counter that keeps multiple transactions from the same wallet from falling out of chronological order. Is that correct?

Coogan | NO MetaMask DMs 03-Sep-21 11:21 AM
Hi there! So the difficulty actually has to do with the processing power of processing the state changes each transaction causes. there's so much that has to be held in memory for hundreds of transactions on each block, and there's a block every ~12s, so you can imagine all the transaction a computer has to process to "sync" to get up to date with the network Once the computer has replayed all the previous transactions and validated each block's transaction, the CPU drops dramatically. But getting to this point is very challenging. this is typically why Ethereum clients now just validate block headers -- this means you take for granted the transactions, and just check the proof of work checks out and the PoW chain continues

1
the network itself is a thing that emerges from a number of different folks running similar software (ethereum clients in this case)
so, to use the language from the section, there are nodes in the network (that's like the fundamental building block of the network, right?)
and the nodes have different roles, and they can hold multiple roles as well -- so the miner node is actually both a full node and running a mining software
Coogan | NO MetaMask DMs
and the nodes have different roles, and they can hold multiple roles as well -- so the miner node is actually both a full node and running a mining software
Kingsley 03-Sep-21 05:20 PM

Coogan | NO MetaMask DMs 03-Sep-21 05:20 PM
which is sort of a built-on feature of a full node. but a miner still has to be a node in the network, passing along valid blocks when they get it (if another miner makes it before they do, for example), passing along transactions, etc!
That link @thedarkjester is great in describing these roles! there's another image i can try to track down real quick too, one sec
1
@Kingsley okay, this might do more harm than good, but here we go:
So these are the four functions of a node (this is for bitcoin but you can abstract away to any blockchain network) -- Wallet (which is the digital key as identity) Full Blockchain (maintaining network state and updating) Miner (validating transactions and creating new blocks) and then Network (passing along valid transactions if they haven't been mined and passing along valid blocks when they emerge)
Okay, now here are those functions mapped on to different nodes in the network : the top one is like a "Full Client" that can do all the things, maintain private keys, pass on transactions, mine etc. There's a full Blockchain node, which has network state and can pass stuff along, there's a Solo Miner, which does all the features of the Full Blockchain Node but adds Mining, and then a "Lightweight" (also called a "light client") wallet, which mainly has the digital identity function (private key) and networking capacity (can pass stuff along but can't do much validation)

Luke's Donut Mind 04-Sep-21 03:37 AM
I'm rather thrilled to understand what all these 'sign this transaction' messages actually are! So if I send a file to you, you can know it comes from me and it is unaltered like so: I create a hash of the file. Then I encrypt the hash of it with my private key. Now I send you the file and this encrypted hash. Then when you get it, you can decrypt the message with my public key, and see the hash of the file. Now you can hash the file and if they are the same, you know that I sent the file, and you know the file has not changed in transit.

How does Ethereum work, anyway?
Odds are you’ve heard about the Ethereum blockchain, whether or not you know what it is. It’s been in the news a lot lately, including the cover of some major magazines, but reading those articles can be like gibberish if you don’t have a foundation for what exactly Ethereum is. So what is it?
1
@paltryarrow7897 Yep, every block has a nonce. It is the only piece of data in a block that can be changed (in order to change the hash output) without breaking the chain. So, when you see a miner talk about "60 megahashes per second", that means that their hardware is literally hashing the block data with a new nonce 60 million times a second.
1
Nick Barker
@paltryarrow7897 Yep, every block has a nonce. It is the only piece of data in a block that can be changed (in order to change the hash output) without breaking the chain. So, when you see a miner talk about "60 megahashes per second", that means that their hardware is literally hashing the block data with a new nonce 60 million times a second.

thedarkjester 04-Sep-21 07:17 AM
Good questions. Each address has a nonce to keep the sequential order of your transactions, so tx A will always be before tx B for this express purpose. This also helps against double spends etc.
So the longest chain might mine tx A 3, 4 or whatever blocks later (edited)

object-hash

nomadicspoon 04-Sep-21 07:59 AM
@Artem Galimzyanov @ndehouche I don't recommend using a third-party package from npm to perform crypto operation, especially if you are unable to audit the package. This is why the crypto package was de-listed from npm and the namespace was reserved and this is what Chapter 1.10 tries to warn us about. It's better to use the built in crypto package that comes with node.js as it is less likely to be tampered with compared to a package found on npm
Artem Galimzyanov
How do you define blockHash() ? - straggling to calculate hash of the block... thnx
nomadicspoon 04-Sep-21 08:00 AM
you'll want to use this method: https://nodejs.org/api/crypto.html#crypto_crypto_createhash_algorithm_options

thedarkjester 05-Sep-21 05:59 AM
Coming back to you on this: 1. Wallet software creates/derives first private parent/master key (from seed) 2. wallet uses Parent/Master private key and derives second private key 3. Different public addresses can be derived from both of the private keys 4. If I send ETH to both public address, the wallet with the master key knows the derivation path and can combine the two balances to give total balance for the wallet/user/overall account. 5. If the wallet sends the total/sum for both addresses to another address it will need to send two transactions with each of those addresses having their own independent nonces and having them signed with the private key for that address. (edited)

SaurabhShukla
can anyone tell what uncle means in ethereum blockchain?
nich 06-Sep-21 01:39 AM
Uncle blocks are created when multiple valid blocks are mined around the same time, one of the blocks get propagated and become the latest block of the new canonical chain (accepted network state). The other blocks that were mined will become "uncles" i.e. not in the canonical chain even though they were valid. So that's why when you deposit or withdraw from exchanges they have you wait a few blocks, to ensure that the transaction was really added into the new canonical chain

Qeustion from https://courses.consensys.net/courses/take/blockchain-developer-bootcamp-registration-2021/multimedia/25083805-additional-material-digital-signatures I'm having trouble understanding what function the unsigned hash serves that the signed hash doesn't. ie, why do we need to hash the message first, and then sign it? if I signed the contents of the message with my private key (without hashing the message), it seems to me we could confirm origin, message integrity, and intent (edited)
Rookie 06-Sep-21 12:55 PM
The hash is a proof so that you know that the public key is actually from the person who sent it. Alice (a-party) needs to know that the public key she received to verify Bobs (b-party) digital signature is actually from Bob. Otherwise Oscar (offensive-party) could perform a man in the middle attach were he just replaces Bob's signature with his own. The hash proves the integrity of the public key during the exchange.

zwilderrr 06-Sep-21 02:52 PM
i think. What I'm hearing is that hashing the message makes for a more efficient way of checking if Alice's message was tampered with. Because, as i think you pointed out, Alice could send her message and a encrypted hash-of-message to Bob. Bob could then decrypt the hash-of-message with Alice's public key and compare it to the message to check for equality. But for efficiency, Alice sends her message and an encrypted message hash that was encrypted with her private key to Bob. Bob hash's the message, decrypts the encrypted message hash, and compares those two for equality.
zwilderrr
i think. What I'm hearing is that hashing the message makes for a more efficient way of checking if Alice's message was tampered with. Because, as i think you pointed out, Alice could send her message and a encrypted hash-of-message to Bob. Bob could then decrypt the hash-of-message with Alice's public key and compare it to the message to check for equality. Bob hash's the message, decrypts the encrypted message hash, and compares those two for equality.
thedarkjester 06-Sep-21 02:54 PM
Yes exactly. Like so: scenario A (data in message) person A encrypts/signs the message with private key person B decrypts the message with public key scenario B (data provided out of message) person A hashes the data and encrypts/signs the hash in the message with private key person B decrypts the message with public key getting hadj person B hashes file and compares the hashes if they match all is good

zwilderrr
Hmm, still not clear. I'm assuming that once Alice encrypts a message with her private key, Bob can confirm Alice authored the message bc he can decrypt it with Alice's public key. If so, why would Alice have to take an extra step to hash the message, and then encrypt that, before sending? Seems like an extra step
samir.yahiaoui 07-Sep-21 01:34 PM
Maybe because in the context of Ethereum/Bitcoin, nothing is ever encrypted. Only signatures are used. In a more general setting, when Alice sends an encrypted message to Bob, she only uses Bob's public key. So bob canot be certain that the sender is Alice, unless she signs the message (this time using her private key).
1
1
zwilderrr
Hmm, still not clear. I'm assuming that once Alice encrypts a message with her private key, Bob can confirm Alice authored the message bc he can decrypt it with Alice's public key. If so, why would Alice have to take an extra step to hash the message, and then encrypt that, before sending? Seems like an extra step
samir.yahiaoui 07-Sep-21 01:41 PM
The point is that if Alice sends an encrypted message to Bob, she only uses Bob's public key. Bob cannot be assured who the sender really is. If on the other hand, Alice signs a message (using her private key), Bob can be certain that the message originated from Alice. Of course, Alice can do both: Encrypt (with Bob's public) and sign (with her private key). In this case, Bob is assured that teh message was delivered securely and that the message originated from Alice.

manuelpires.eth 07-Sep-21 03:42 PM
function createBlock(data) { var block = { index: Blockchain.blocks.length, prevHash: Blockchain.blocks[Blockchain.blocks.length - 1].hash, data, timestamp: Date.now(), }; block.hash = blockHash(block); return block; }
that should work @Sama , you first create an object block without a hash, then calculate the hash of that and put it inside the block object before returning it

function createBlock(data) { var block = { index: Blockchain.blocks.length, prevHash: Blockchain.blocks[Blockchain.blocks.length - 1].hash, data, timestamp: Date.now(), }; block.hash = blockHash(block); return block; }

samir.yahiaoui 07-Sep-21 03:55 PM
I believe the difficulty threshold is set independently from the blocks. In the case of Bitcoin, it is set based on the total mining power and it dynamically increases/decreases based on how much hashing power is in the network .

Coming back to you on this: 1. Wallet software creates/derives first private parent/master key (from seed) 2. wallet uses Parent/Master private key and derives second private key 3. Different public addresses can be derived from both of the private keys 4. If I send ETH to both public address, the wallet with the master key knows the derivation path and can combine the two balances to give total balance for the wallet/user/overall account. 5. If the wallet sends the total/sum for both addresses to another address it will need to send two transactions with each of those addresses having their own independent nonces and having them signed with the private key for that address. thedarkjester 08-Sep-21 05:23 AM
Could I ask you to rephrase your question please, not sure what it is then. There are two types of nonces: 1 for the entire block and proof of work and 2 the sequential nonce/counter for the transactions associated to one address. If three addresses are sending transactions in one block, they will each have their own nonce per tx. E.g. address 1 may have nonce 2 for their second tx and address 2 may have nonce 500 for their 500th tx (edited)
Satori 08-Sep-21 05:26 AM
Let's say you send a transaction at time X and I send a txn at time X+1 . What happens if your TX gets picked up by a miner and included in a block which gets orphaned. And my TX gets into the longest chain. Does this mean that your tx will be mined after mine even tho it was send before ? When your miners' block gets orphaned what happens to your tx ? Does it go back to the pending queue ?
Does this help ? Is it a valid question ?
thedarkjester 08-Sep-21 05:31 AM
Valid question
The x+1 won't be included in a block because the nonce will be higher. It will hang in the pool until x is processed. Some nodes may not accept it if the nonce is out of sequence, but normally sits in the pool until x is processed. If the nonce was set as the same however if x wasn't processed already, it may be included first (sometimes paying a higher gas fee like this is done to speed up a slow tx) (edited)
If x or x+1 with the same nonce is processed then the other will be rejected
Satori 08-Sep-21 05:57 AM
You're referring to the block nonce right ?
Isn't it separate for each miner ? Just a counter used to start hashing.
Each miner decides which txs to mine and which not (the MEV problem being a consequence).
So txs X and X+1 are completely separate in my understanding
thedarkjester 08-Sep-21 07:06 AM
The block nonce is the proof of work value/solution being mined or searched for. The transaction nonce is relative to each address. So yes, tx X and X+1 are two different transactions where if transaction nonce on X is 1, X+1 should be 2. X+1 won't be included in a block until the longest chain has a transaction with a transaction (X) containing a nonce one lower.
1

Satori 08-Sep-21 08:21 AM
This isn't true. The nonce is per account and we're talking about 2 separate accounts (mine and yours). Miners decide what to pick and in what order, the mev problem wouldn't exist otherwise.
thedarkjester 08-Sep-21 09:00 AM
I think we are saying the same thing and talking past each other. MEV as I understand it is the ability for a miner to pick and choose between my or your transactions to frontrun or pick those with higher fees. The miner can't adjust the nonce in my signed transaction. My account/address still needs sequential flow. Your account also needs sequential flow. My flow is not the same as your flow. My tx X can't have my tx X+1 put before it. (edited)

In the Ethereum network, transactions are sent from and to addresses. The public keys are not typically shown. This begs the question: How does the signature verification occur, since we hear all the time that the private key is used to sign, and the public key of the sender is used to verify. How bob can verify a transaction that originates from Alice, if Alice's public key is never broadcast to the network? I am under the impression that for the signature type used in the Ethereum transactions (ECDSA), you don't need the public key. All what's published is the pair (r,s) which alongside with the curve characteristics (Secp261), is sufficient to verify that the signature is valid. Can anyone confirm my understanding? Or indicate what I'm missing? Thank you! (edited)

const verifyBlock = (block) => { switch(true) { case block.data === null: case block.prevHash === null: case typeof block.index === "number" && block.index < 0: case Blockchain.blocks[0].hash !== "000000": case block.index !== 0 && block.hash !== blockHash(block): return false default: return true } }

Craig Banach 09-Sep-21 06:22 PM
I used a big return expression:
function verifyBlock(block, prevBlockHash) { const hash = block.hash; delete block.hash; const computedHash = blockHash(block); return (block.data && block.data.length !== 0) && (block.index === 0 || block.prevHash && block.prevHash.length !== 0 && block.prevHash === prevBlockHash) && (block.index >= 0) && (hash === computedHash || (block.index === 0 && hash === "000000")); }
1

Craig Banach 09-Sep-21 06:31 PM
Because you don't check whether the prevHash is equal to the hash of the previous block, you could insert a 'rogue' block in the chain somewhere. You should check that block.prevHash is equal to the hash of the previous block in your verifyBlock method.
waffs
@MatricksDeCoder so after all 21million bitcoin blocks have been mined there are still going to be blocks for transactions? The question is then without mining how is consensus possible at this point in the network for new transactions?
Craig Banach 09-Sep-21 06:37 PM
My understanding of Bitcoin isn't as good as Ethereum, but I believe that the issuance (amount of bitcoins released per block) will continually decrease so that the un-mined bitcoins will be > 0 for a long time. Once that is over, miners will be solely rewarded by the transaction fees. See: https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Controlled_supply#Projected_Bitcoins_Long_Term Also there is no block limit as far as I know. (edited)
Controlled supply

trx314
hi, in the video "What is a Block", I understood well who the validity of the block is validated by the nodes (by checking the that the hash is consistent with the difficulty level), however I did not understand how the actual transactions of the present block are validated.
Craig Banach 09-Sep-21 06:46 PM
If I have 1 ETH and try to send you 2 ETH, then that is an invalid transaction. All trustworthy nodes will check each transaction for such errors and reject a block with said errors.

keith 09-Sep-21 09:44 PM
Hi all, can anyone explain how the Bitcoin network adjusts the mining difficulty? Specifically, I'm trying to understand how the network as a whole knows how to adjust the difficulty if the hashrate goes up or down and how the network decides and agrees upon the new difficulty level
MatricksDeCoder 09-Sep-21 09:59 PM
In simple terms, say it took 5seconds to generate blocks and we want average to be around 15-17seconds. The difficulty will be increased. So adjustment is based on timestamp differences between blocks. The difficulty is a property on the blocks block.difficulty. So when miners are working current block they use the difficulty as informed by previous block to determine what hash is needed below that difficulty.
MatricksDeCoder

So when miners are working current block they use the difficulty as informed by previous block to determine what hash is needed below that difficulty.

Craig Banach 10-Sep-21 03:33 AM
Your verifyBlock function always checks the final, penultimate and genesis block each time you call it (you call it once for each block). My recommended way to fix this would be to pass in the current block and previous block hash into the VerifyBlock function in a loop. (Using a for loop might make this easier to do initially). I also believe the intent of the task was to call verifyBlock 9 times from inside verifyChain. (But that's less important than the above). If you're struggling with the above, leave another message and I can help further.
ringman007

Craig Banach 10-Sep-21 03:38 AM
Also the way you check the prevHash and data strings for not being empty has undesirable effects. An empty string '' will successfully pass when we don't want it to, and the valid string 'undefined' will fail when checking the block.data. (edited)

Craig Banach 10-Sep-21 05:19 AM
There's still some problems with your solution. You loop over the blockchain blocks, but you use the same 'nowBlock' every loop. I've re-written your verifyBlock function below to give you some pointers. Can you set up your code to call it once for every block? N.B. The parameter prevHash should be the 'hash of the previous block' and not the 'prevHash of the current block'. Also you can pass in null for prevHash when passing in the genesis block.
function verifyBlock(currentBlock, prevHash) { if ( // Check if genesis block first (currentBlock.hash === '000000' && currentBlock.index === 0) || // Check for standard case (currentBlock.data !== '' && currentBlock.prevHash !== '' && currentBlock.index > 0 && prevHash === currentBlock.prevHash && currentBlock.hash === blockHash(currentBlock)) ) { return true; } else { return false; } }
 (edited)

Craig Banach 10-Sep-21 09:33 AM
Only a message signed with your private key will be 'valid' when de-crypted with your public key. Nodes will check this when checking that a transaction is valid.
Craig Banach
Only a message signed with your private key will be 'valid' when de-crypted with your public key. Nodes will check this when checking that a transaction is valid.
trx314 10-Sep-21 09:40 AM
so when the full nodes receive the blocks from the miners, they also check the signatures of each transaction included in the blocks?
trx314
so when the full nodes receive the blocks from the miners, they also check the signatures of each transaction included in the blocks?
Craig Banach 10-Sep-21 09:44 AM
I believe (but can't confirm) that each node will execute the instructions for each transaction using the EVM itself and check the hash it gets itself against the supplied hash given by the block proposer. So if my transaction is transaction #6 in a block to send 2 USDT to you, then it will re-play the transaction using the current state of the blockchain and if it succeeds, then it will treat it as valid. (edited)
Sharding is expected to bring efficiencies to this process whereby every node doesn't need to verify every transaction.

datadawg-11
for a nonce value in the pow exercises, how big can this random number be, is it 0-9 or 0-100. I think it doesnt matter too much as the the timestamp changes but curious if there is a set limit
guru 11-Sep-21 10:23 AM
The nonce is usually a very large random number. There have to be enough options of nonce, so that one of them will result in the hash being less than the threshold. If the nonce lies only between 0-100 for example, there will only be 100 different hashes and its quite possible that none of them solve the POW puzzle. bl.nonce = Math.floor(Math.random() * 1E7); (edited)

samir.yahiaoui 11-Sep-21 06:10 PM
@Gene Just saw your question in the live chat with @Coogan | NO MetaMask DMs about possible collisions of Ethereum addresses. I think addresses are 160 bits (40 hexadecimal integers) which in theory makes it possible that two public keys to have the same address. So the probability of having two public keys have the same address in the order of 1 divided by 2^160. This is about 0.0000000000000001 Another reference that might help show how difficult that to occur is that SHA-1 (which is a 160 bits hash) have only one known collision after 20 years of usage. https://security.googleblog.com/2017/02/announcing-first-sha1-collision.html (edited)
Announcing the first SHA1 collision

Phas0r
Hi, I have a question pls. In the video on the course website entitled "Cryptographic Fundamentals and Metamask", at timestamp 39:31, Coogan send a message that he has hashed with his private key ("Hello world") and mentions anyone can verify he holds the private key. He shares his Ethereum Account and Message signature which are needed to verify this. Am I right in thinking that the Ethereum account and message signature are essentially the public key here, since we need a public key to decrypt a message that has been encrypted with the associated private key? Thanks
thedarkjester 13-Sep-21 12:40 PM
The message itself isn't part of the 'public key'. The sender takes a message ('hello world'), hashes that, becomes ab232 (or whatever). This hash is then signed/encrypted by the sender with their private key. The recipient can then take the sender's public key and decrypt the message to get the hash. If the recipient then hashes 'hello world', they can then compare the hashes. If they match then it can be inferred that the sender sent that hash.
1
If it were a file being sent, the sender would hash the file and send the message with that hash. They can then provide the file to the recipient somehow (maybe some service that you distrust). If the recipient hashes the file and compares the hash to the one in the message, they know the file was not tampered with by anyone along the way.

arnold 13-Sep-21 10:18 PM
@Tulio that expression is called template literal and it can be used to generate strings based on a set of variables and custom strings. The example you shared is quite confusing because it has a lot of variables and symbols. We could use this snipped to illustrate a simple example:
const subject = 'Blockchain'; const templateLiteralExpression = `We are learning about ${subject} 🤘🏼`; console.log(templateLiteralExpression);
As you can see its possible to add custom strings and substitute variables (we can even add emojis ) Hope it helps, you can take a look to the next link to read more about this. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Template_literals

From what I could see, instead of creating a brand new input and signing it using the authorizeInput function, you are simply pointing the input to a slice of the sortedInputs, which basically points to one of the outputs from the previous transaction. So the output from the previous transaction is being signed instead // Array of UTXOs we will spend const spent_sortedInputs = sortedInputs.slice(0, UTXO_counter); // Sign the UTXOs we will spend, and add them to trData.inputs for (let input of spent_sortedInputs) { const newInput = {...input}; trData.inputs.push(await Blockchain.authorizeInput(newInput, fromAccount.privKey)) } ------------------------------ try modifying the code as below and see if it helps for (let input of spent_sortedInputs) { const newInput = {...input}; // This is to make sure that a brand new input is created and signed trData.inputs.push(await Blockchain.authorizeInput(newInput, fromAccount.privKey)) }

Hash chain
A hash chain is the successive application of a cryptographic hash function to a piece of data. In computer security, a hash chain is a method to produce many one-time keys from a single key or password. For non-repudiation a hash function can be applied successively to additional pieces of data in order to record the chronology of data's exist...

hello in the whitepaper exercises, the Proof of Work readme says: Remember, 4 bits is one hexadecimal digit character. Why are these 4 bits and regular characters 8 bits ?
g2dx
hello in the whitepaper exercises, the Proof of Work readme says: Remember, 4 bits is one hexadecimal digit character. Why are these 4 bits and regular characters 8 bits ?
guru 24-Sep-21 03:16 PM
Hexadecimal encoding has only 16 different digit characters 0-9, A, B, C, D, E and F. 4-bits are necessary and sufficient to represent ONE of these 16 digits.

sw1-1 01-Oct-21 03:33 AM
Hi, I have a question
I understand why we need hash functions to be fast enough for processing but slow enough for security. But I do not get why a very fast hash function can cause a collision. Any Explanation?
Paddy 01-Oct-21 04:07 AM
@sw1-1 Based on my limited understanding, a fast has function probably doesn't behave sufficiently "randomly" in the way that it outputs values, therefore increasing the chance that two different inputs give the same output. The thought is that if a function is easy to compute then there is unlikely to be enough diversity in the range of possible outputs because easy computations are easy to predict the behaviour of, and then it wouldn't be a very good hash function. (edited)
I was wondering, could anyone explain the concept of a "signed hash" as used in the section called "Additional Material: Digital Signatures"?
Nathaniel K. Blanquel 06-Oct-21 02:56 PM
@Paddy I think a signed hash is just a hash that created using the private key of an "author". That way the signature is unique for that private key, and because it's a hash it can't be reversed. The only problem like with all hashes is collisions.
sw1-1 17-Oct-21 11:38 AM
Light Nodes don't participate in checking the validity of the advancing network state, WHY?
sw1-1
Light Nodes don't participate in checking the validity of the advancing network state, WHY?
thedarkjester 17-Oct-21 12:14 PM
Most likely due to the amount of data they keep. The idea is to be a gateway to the network.
sw1-1
I understand why we need hash functions to be fast enough for processing but slow enough for security. But I do not get why a very fast hash function can cause a collision. Any Explanation?
thedarkjester 17-Oct-21 12:20 PM
The idea here is more like @sw1-1 is saying: The hash function should be quick enough to take a given input and produce a result, but also slow enough that if you take a computed hash, you can't just throw immense processing power at it brute forcing with random values. It also needs to have enough entropy or behave such that the likelihood of two values producing the same hash for those two values is reasonable impossible.
Paddy
I was wondering, could anyone explain the concept of a "signed hash" as used in the section called "Additional Material: Digital Signatures"?
thedarkjester 17-Oct-21 12:25 PM
In the example some existing data was passed through a hash function to produce a hash. This hash was then encrypted/signed with the private key of the sender. If the recipient was to get the same data and hash it, they could compare it to the decrypted one from the sender (using sender's public key) and have evidence the data to deal with is valid. An example is I send you a large pdf in an email with the signed hash data as well. You could hash the file, compare to what is in the signed hash data and if matching you can be assured it wasn't tampered with. Consider gigabyte size files from a download mirror with the hash on the site - if it is signed by the uploader, you could verify it no matter who was hosting the file. (edited)
thedarkjester
Most likely due to the amount of data they keep. The idea is to be a gateway to the network.
sw1-1 17-Oct-21 01:09 PM
They are network nodes which are simply submitting transactions to the network, how is related to being the gateway to the network? or how is this an indication of the amount of data they keep?
sw1-1
They are network nodes which are simply submitting transactions to the network, how is related to being the gateway to the network? or how is this an indication of the amount of data they keep?
thedarkjester 17-Oct-21 01:33 PM
By gateway I mean the means to submit transactions and get balances etc. If I want to know I am getting the correct data from the network vs. some potentially untrusted rpc endpoint I can run a light node that will bootstrap with trusted nodes. In terms of data, if I don't have the full history or a lot of state data I can't go and do verifications with the future transactions that are wanting to be executed. If I don't have GBs of storage to spare, then a light node may be preferable.
Exported 868 message(s)
